articles.headline: 9/11 Victims’ Remains Disposed Of in Landfill
articles.snippet: The disclosure came as an independent panel concluded that the Dover Air Force Base mortuary should have more oversight, training of employees and inspections.
articles.abstract: The disclosure came as an independent panel concluded that the Dover Air Force Base mortuary should have more oversight, training of employees and inspections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The mortuary at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware disposed of body parts of some victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks by burning them and dumping the ashes in a landfill, an independent panel said in a report to the Pentagon released on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Romney Regains Stride With Victories in 2 States
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney successfully fended off a challenge from Rick Santorum in Michigan, a key battleground state, helping his chances of becoming the Republican nominee.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney successfully fended off a challenge from Rick Santorum in Michigan, a key battleground state, helping his chances of becoming the Republican nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTHFIELD, Mich. — Mitt Romney fought back a vigorous challenge from Rick Santorum in Michigan on Tuesday, narrowly carrying his native state, and won the Arizona primary in a pair of contests that reasserted his control over the Republican presidential race as it advances to critical Super Tuesday contests next week.

articles.headline: Stimulus Is Maligned, but Options Were Few
articles.snippet: Republicans have condemned President Obama’s American Recovery and Reinvestment Act as an unmitigated disaster, but would they have responded to the recession differently?
articles.abstract: Republicans have condemned President Obama’s American Recovery and Reinvestment Act as an unmitigated disaster, but would they have responded to the recession differently?
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the winter of 2009 and the United States economy was shrinking. In the last three months of 2008 the economy had contracted at an annual rate of 8.9 percent, the sharpest decline in more than half a century. It shrank at a 6.9 percent rate the next quarter. By February 2009 the country had lost more than five million jobs.

articles.headline: Romney Faces Stubborn Question, Despite Victories
articles.snippet: Can a Northeasterner with a history of ideological migration win the nomination in the Tea Party era?
articles.abstract: Can a Northeasterner with a history of ideological migration win the nomination in the Tea Party era?
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTHFIELD, Mich. — After 5 caucuses, 6 primaries, 20 debates and $30 million in television commercials, Mitt Romney leaves here facing the same stubborn question: Can a onetime Northeastern governor with a history of ideological migration win the Republican presidential nomination in the era of the Tea Party, with all its demands of political purity and passion?

articles.headline: U.S. Sees Iran Attacks as Likely if Israel Strikes
articles.snippet: American officials assessed that Iran would retaliate to an Israeli strike by launching missiles on Israel and terrorist-style attacks on United States civilian and military personnel overseas.
articles.abstract: American officials assessed that Iran would retaliate to an Israeli strike by launching missiles on Israel and terrorist-style attacks on United States civilian and military personnel overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials who have assessed the likely Iranian responses to any attack by Israel on its nuclear program believe that Iran would retaliate by launching missiles on Israel and terrorist-style attacks on United States civilian and military personnel overseas.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, Helene Cooper and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: North Koreans Agree to Freeze Nuclear Work; U.S. to Give Aid
articles.snippet: North Korea’s surprise announcement raised the possibility of ending an impasse that has allowed its nuclear program to continue for years without international oversight.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s surprise announcement raised the possibility of ending an impasse that has allowed its nuclear program to continue for years without international oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea announced on Wednesday that it would suspend its nuclear weapons tests and uranium enrichment and allow international inspectors to monitor activities at its main nuclear complex. The surprise announcement raised the possibility of ending a diplomatic impasse that has allowed the country’s nuclear program to continue for years without international oversight.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Chairman Sees Modest Growth
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke said the recent rise in oil prices had not affected the Fed’s view that the economy would expand at from 2.2 to 2.7 percent this year.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke said the recent rise in oil prices had not affected the Fed’s view that the economy would expand at from 2.2 to 2.7 percent this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday that the central bank retained its modest expectations for the American economy this year, despite some recent signs of stronger growth.
